skills.name: Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)

explanations.A: Everything inside the brackets is squared, or multiplied by itself, so another way of writing this is 3ğ‘ Ã— 3ğ‘. Remembering that multiplication is commutative (the order doesn't matter), we can write this as 3 Ã— 3 Ã— ğ‘ Ã— ğ‘ which simplifies to 9ğ‘Â².

explanations.C: You have squared the a, but forgotten about the 3. As the 3 is in the brackets, it also needs to be squared.
explanations.D: You have squared the 3, but forgotten about the a. As the a is in the brackets, it also needs to be squared.

explanations.A: You have cubed the p, but forgotten about the 2. As the 2 is in the brackets, it also needs to be cubed.
